Federated Learning in Unreliable and Resource-Constrained Cellular Wireless Networks

Mohammad Salehi and Ekram Hossain, FIEEE The authors are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Manitoba, Canada (emails: salehim@myumanitoba.ca, Ekram.Hossain@umanitoba.ca). E. Hossain is the corresponding author. The work was supported by a Discovery Grant from the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC).
Abstract

With growth in the number of smart devices and advancements in their hardware, in recent years, data-driven machine learning techniques have drawn significant attention. However, due to privacy and communication issues, it is not possible to collect this data at a centralized location. Federated learning is a machine learning setting where the centralized location trains a learning model over remote devices. Federated learning algorithms cannot be employed in the real world scenarios unless they consider unreliable and resource-constrained nature of the wireless medium. In this paper, we propose a federated learning algorithm that is suitable for cellular wireless networks. We prove its convergence, and provide the optimal scheduling policy that maximizes the convergence rate. We also study the effect of local computation steps and communication steps on the convergence of the proposed algorithm. We prove, in practice, federated learning algorithms may solve a different problem than the one that they have been employed for if the unreliability of wireless channels is neglected. Finally, through numerous experiments on real and synthetic datasets, we demonstrate the convergence of our proposed algorithm.

Index Terms:
Machine learning, federated learning, cellular wireless networks, success probability, signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR), stochastic geometry, convergence analysis

I Introduction

I-A Motivation

With the rapid growth in Internet-of-Things (IoT) applications and increase in the computational and storage power of smart devices, modern distributed networks generate a huge amount of data everyday [1]. Owing to this reason, data-driven machine learning techniques have gained significant attention in recent years. Currently, most of the existing machine learning techniques are centralized, i.e. they assume all data is available at a centralized location, where a central processor trains a powerful learning method on the data [2]. However, transferring data from user devices to the centralized location violates users’ privacy [3]. To cope with this issue, federated learning has been introduced where a learning model is trained over remote devices under the control of the centralized location, called server [1, 3, 4]. Specifically, in federated learning (FL), the server broadcasts the global model parameters to the remote devices. Each remote device uses its local dataset to update the global model, and then transmits the updated local model to the server. After aggregating the local models, the server updates the global model and repeats the whole procedure. As an example, consider the task of next-word prediction on mobile phones, where a language model predicts the most probable next word or phrase based on a small amount of user-generated preceding text. To maintain the users privacy, instead of transmitting the raw text data to the server and training a predictor at the server, we use federated learning [5, 1].

Although the above definition of federated learning seems similar to parallel optimization and distributed machine learning in datacenters, due to the following challenges, it needs to be treated separately: i) In federated learning, connections between the remote devices and the server111In a cellular wireless network, the base stations (BSs) can act as the servers. are unreliable and slow, ii) different devices in the network have different systems characteristics (systems heterogeneity), and iii) training data are not independently and identically distributed (statistical heterogeneity) [6, 7]. Since data is non-i.i.d. (not independently and identically distributed) across devices, all devices must participate in the learning process. However, due to the systems heterogeneity, which includes variable computation and communication capabilities at different devices, and limited amount of available resources such as bandwidth (e.g. number of resource blocks) for communication, full device participation at each round of communication is not possible. Moreover, in reality, transmission success probability is different for different devices, even when they all have the same hardware. Specifically, transmission success probability for devices that are located closer to the server is generally higher than that for devices that are located far. Thus, unless this issue is considered at the time of updating the global model, the updated global model will be biased towards cell centre devices’ local models.

I-B Related Works

To reduce the communication rounds of FL, three main approaches have been employed: quantization, sparsification, and local updates [8]. In this paper, we study local updates, where between any two aggregation steps in consecutive rounds, each device performs multiple local update steps. In this regard, [2, 9, 10] studied the convergence of communication-efficient FL with local updates for convex and non-convex problems. However, it was assumed that all of the devices participate in the aggregation step, which is obviously not possible when the number of available resource blocks is limited. To tackle this problem, in [11, 12, 6, 7, 13, 14], at the beginning of each round, the server samples a subset of devices and allocates the available resource blocks to these devices. After performing local update steps, the BS aggregates the local models of the chosen (scheduled) devices and updates the global model. The works in [11, 12, 6, 7, 13, 14] assumed that the BS successfully receives the local models of all the scheduled devices, and they designed the global model update step based on this assumption. However, this is not true in reality. In fact, not only is the success probability less than one, but also it is different for different devices. Clearly, to update the global model we need to include both scheduling policy and success probability.

To better understand, consider a scenario with two devices and two resource blocks, where both devices are scheduled for sharing their updated local models with the server. Assume that the success probability is 1 for device one and is 0.1 for device two. In this scenario, the server receives the local model of device two once in every ten rounds on average, while the local model of device one is always successfully received. Obviously, without considering this aspect of wireless communications, the global model is biased towards device one at the end of the learning process.

To the best of our knowledge, only the work in [15] considered the effect of success probability on the convergence of FL. Similar to [16], [15] solved the FL problem using primal-dual optimization method. However, when strong duality is not guaranteed, this method may not be useful [12]. Also, in the analysis, the FL global objective is assumed to be a function of linear combination of model parameters and the input features. Thus, convergence analysis for this method cannot be extended to other machine learning techniques.

I-C Contributions and Organization

The most common federated learning algorithm in the literature is FedAvg (federated averaging) [11], which lacks convergence analysis. Several works in the literature made steps towards analyzing convergence of FedAvg by modifying the algorithm. For example, [6] proposed a different averaging scheme for FedAvg, and derived the convergence rate of the modified algorithm. [12] proposed FedProx, which is a generalization of FedAvg obtained by adding a proximal term to the local objectives. Recently, [7] has proposed SCAFFOLD which improves FedAvg by adding a correction term, called client drift, to local updates. However, as we discussed in the previous subsection, these works and all other related works do not consider the effect of transmission success probability.

In the above context, the major contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    We propose an FL algorithm that is suitable for unreliable and resource-constrained wireless systems. In particular, for an FL system in a cellular wireless network, the BS selects a subset of devices at each round and updates the global model based on their updated local models and success probabilities. We use stochastic geometry tools to approximately calculate the success probability for each device.

  • •

    Our proposed FL algorithm solves the FL problem in the primal domain. We prove that, for strongly convex and smooth problems, the algorithm converges on non-i.i.d data with rate 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{T}).

  • •

    We study two difference scheduling (sampling) policies. We also explain how to achieve the optimal scheduling policy based on the derived convergence rate.

  • •

    We study the effect of number of computation steps and communication steps on the convergence rate.

  • •

    We show that the existing works, which do not include the transmission success probability in the global model update step (e.g. those in [11, 12, 6, 7]), will not be suitable for a wireless communication environment, since they may converge to the solution of a different FL problem when the success probability is different for different devices.

  • •

    We verify the convergence of our proposed FL algorithm by experimenting over real and synthetic datasets. We also compare our results with centralized full batch gradient descent which can be considered as a benchmark for our algorithm.

The organization of the rest of the paper is as follows. In Section II, we introduce the system model and propose our FL algorithm. Then, in Section III, we provide the convergence analysis of our FL algorithm. Further analysis of the proposed FL algorithm and comparison with related algorithms are provided in Section IV. In Section V, we present the simulation results. Finally, Section VI concludes the paper. A summary of the major notations used in the paper is given in Table I.

II System Model, Assumptions, and Proposed FL Algorithm

II-A Network Model

Consider a single-tier cellular network. The locations of the BSs follow a homogeneous Poisson point process (PPP) ΦΦ\Phi of intensity λ𝜆\lambda, and each BS serves the user devices that are located in its Voronoi cell, i.e. each device is associated to its nearest BS. In each cell, N𝑁N devices are uniformly distributed; we use subscript k𝑘k to denote the k𝑘k-th nearest device to the BS. Thus, rksubscript𝑟𝑘r_{k} denotes the distance between the serving BS and its k𝑘k-th nearest device. Each BS allocates M𝑀M resource blocks for the learning process, where M≤N𝑀𝑁M\leq N.

II-B Federated Learning

In order to learn a statistical model from the distributed data across user devices, BS tries to solve the following distributed optimization problem:

Since the information is distributed across multiple devices, a BS cannot directly solve (1). Therefore, the BS and the devices collaboratively learn the optimal model parameters w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} 222w∗=arg⁡min⁡F​(w)superscript𝑤𝐹𝑤w^{*}=\arg\min F(w) by following an iterative algorithm. Specifically, after initializing the model parameters at the BS at time 00, each iteration (round) of the algorithm comprises: 1) Sampling and broadcast, 2) Local stochastic gradient descent (SGD), and 3) Aggregation and averaging. In the following, we discuss each of these steps in detail for an iteration that starts at time t𝑡t. This iteration is also shown in Fig. 1.

Sampling and Broadcasting: Due to the limited number of available resource blocks, the BS selects a group of devices at time t𝑡t and broadcasts its model parameters to these devices. In this paper, we consider two different sampling schemes.

In Scheme I, the BS uniformly selects M𝑀M devices out of N𝑁N devices without replacement, i.e. each device uses at most one resource block. Let us denote the set of the selected (scheduled) devices at time t𝑡t by 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t}. For Scheme I, device k𝑘k uses qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} resource blocks on average at sampling time t𝑡t, where

qk=𝔼​[∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮t​(m))]=MN.subscript𝑞𝑘𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝑚𝑀𝑁\displaystyle q_{k}=\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}_{t}(m)\right)\right]=\frac{M}{N}. (3)

𝒮t​(m)subscript𝒮𝑡𝑚\mathcal{S}_{t}(m) in the above equation denotes the index of the scheduled device at time t𝑡t for resource block m𝑚m, and 𝟏(.)\mathbf{1}(.) is the indicator function.

In Scheme II, at time t𝑡t, for resource block m𝑚m, the BS samples a device with replacement from N𝑁N devices with probabilities {q^k}subscript^𝑞𝑘\{\hat{q}_{k}\}. Thus, sampling is independently and identically distributed over m𝑚m, and some devices may use more that one resource block. For Scheme II, we have

qk=𝔼​[∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮t​(m))]=M​q^k.subscript𝑞𝑘𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝑚𝑀subscript^𝑞𝑘\displaystyle q_{k}=\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}_{t}(m)\right)\right]=M\hat{q}_{k}. (4)

II-C Interference, SINR, and Success Probability

In this subsection, we study the success probability of device k𝑘k at its associated BS, given that it is scheduled to transmit over resource block m𝑚m. Due to the stationarity of the homogeneous PPP [17], we can consider the location of this BS as the origin of our coordination system.

Before studying the uplink success probability, it is worth mentioning that, in this paper, we assume that downlink communication is always successful, i.e. all the scheduled devices successfully receive the global model parameters. This is a valid assumption since the BS can transmit with more power compared to the devices; moreover, the BS can allocate more than one resource block for broadcasting the global model parameters. However, due to power constraint at user devices and limited number of allocated resource blocks to each scheduled device, we consider that uplink transmissions may not be successful at an aggregation step.

To increase the success probability during the aggregation steps, we assume that all scheduled devices transmit their local model parameters for ℓℓ\ell times, and the BS employs selection combining, i.e. it uses the highest received SINR to recover the local model parameters transmitted over resource block m𝑚m. Therefore,

Uksubscript𝑈𝑘\displaystyle U_{k} =\displaystyle= 𝔼​[𝟏​(SINRk,m>θ)∣k∈𝒮t​(m)]𝔼delimited-[]conditional1subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝜃𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝑚\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbf{1}\left(\text{SINR}_{k,m}>\theta\right)\mid k\in\mathcal{S}_{t}(m)\right]
=\displaystyle= 𝔼​[𝟏​(max⁡{SINRk,m​(1),SINRk,m​(2),…,SINRk,m​(ℓ)}>θ)∣k∈𝒮t​(m)],𝔼delimited-[]conditional1subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚1subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚2…subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚ℓ𝜃𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝑚\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbf{1}\left(\max\left\{\text{SINR}_{k,m}(1),\text{SINR}_{k,m}(2),...,\text{SINR}_{k,m}(\ell)\right\}>\theta\right)\mid k\in\mathcal{S}_{t}(m)\right],

where SINRk,m​(i)subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝑖\text{SINR}_{k,m}(i) denotes the received SINR from device k𝑘k over resource block m𝑚m at i𝑖i-th transmission attempt of an aggregation step.

Since the success event is identically distributed across different iterations (rounds) of the algorithm for device k𝑘k, SINRk,m​(i)subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝑖\text{SINR}_{k,m}(i) is not indexed by the iteration number. Moreover, at the aggregation step of each iteration, interference and fading are identically distributed across different resource blocks; thus, we can omit subscript m𝑚m from SINRk,m​(i)subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝑖\text{SINR}_{k,m}(i) since its statistics does not depend on m𝑚m. With this in mind, we can write

SINRk​(i)=hk​(i)​rk−αI​(i)+σ2=hk​(i)​rk−α∑x∈ΦIhx​(i)​‖x‖−α+σ2,subscriptSINR𝑘𝑖subscriptℎ𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝛼𝐼𝑖superscript𝜎2subscriptℎ𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝛼subscript𝑥subscriptΦIsubscriptℎ𝑥𝑖superscriptnorm𝑥𝛼superscript𝜎2\displaystyle\text{SINR}_{k}(i)=\frac{h_{k}(i)r_{k}^{-\alpha}}{I(i)+\sigma^{2}}=\frac{h_{k}(i)r_{k}^{-\alpha}}{\sum_{x\in\Phi_{\rm I}}h_{x}(i)\|x\|^{-\alpha}+\sigma^{2}}, (9)

where σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the normalized noise power (noise power to the device transmit power). I​(i)=∑x∈ΦIhx​(i)​‖x‖−α𝐼𝑖subscript𝑥subscriptΦIsubscriptℎ𝑥𝑖superscriptnorm𝑥𝛼I(i)=\sum_{x\in\Phi_{\rm I}}h_{x}(i)\|x\|^{-\alpha} is the interference at i𝑖i-th transmission attempt with ΦIsubscriptΦI\Phi_{\rm I} denoting the set of interferers. Here hx​(i)subscriptℎ𝑥𝑖h_{x}(i) denotes the small-scale fading gain between a device at location x𝑥x and the BS at the origin. We consider Rayleigh fading, i.e. hx∼exp⁡(1)similar-tosubscriptℎ𝑥1h_{x}\sim\exp(1), and it is i.i.d. across i𝑖i (different transmission attempts) and x𝑥x (different locations). α𝛼\alpha denotes the path-loss exponent. Since the set of interferers remains the same during different transmission attempts of one aggregation step, the success events over one resource block during an aggregation step, are temporally correlated.

It is also worth mentioning that we can easily extend our framework to more complex scenarios including uplink transmission with power control as in [18], multiple input multiple output antenna systems as in [19, 20], millimeter wave as in [21].

III Convergence Analysis of the Proposed Federated Learning Algorithm

III-A Convergence Rate

In this section, we prove the convergence of the proposed algorithm. In this regard, we first introduce additional notations and assumptions that are required to derive the convergence rate.

Following the same notation as in [6], for time t𝑡t, we define

  • •

So far we have assumed that each device uses only one data sample at each local update step. In the following, we discuss using mini-batches with more than one data sample at the local update steps.

IV Further Analysis and Comparison

In this section, we provide a further discussion on the proposed federated learning algorithm using Theorem 1. Specifically, we first study the impact of number of iterations (rounds), number of local update steps at each round, and number of transmission attempts at each aggregation step in each round; then we find the optimal scheduling policy that maximizes the convergence rate. Finally, we compare our algorithm with the works that do not consider the transmission success probability and prove its significance.

IV-A Effects of Number of Computation and Communication Steps

To study the impact of number of rounds (K𝐾K444According to the definition, K=T/E𝐾𝑇𝐸K=T/E in Theorem 1.), number of local update steps during each round (E𝐸E), and number of transmission attempts at each aggregation step in each round (ℓℓ\ell), we use a simpler form of Theorem 1.

Corollary 1.

When ηt=2μ​(γ+t)subscript𝜂𝑡2𝜇𝛾𝑡\eta_{t}=\frac{2}{\mu(\gamma+t)} with γ=max⁡{8​Lμ,E}𝛾8𝐿𝜇𝐸\gamma=\max\left\{8\frac{L}{\mu},E\right\}, after the averaging step at the K𝐾K-th round, we have

𝔼​[F​(wT)−F∗]≤L/μK​E​[2μ​(∑k=1Npk2​σk2+6​L​Γ+8​(E−1)2​G2+4​E2​G2​B)+μ​γ2​‖w0−w∗‖2],𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝑇superscript𝐹𝐿𝜇𝐾𝐸delimited-[]2𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘26𝐿Γ8superscript𝐸12superscript𝐺24superscript𝐸2superscript𝐺2𝐵𝜇𝛾2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑤0superscript𝑤2\mathbb{E}\left[F(w_{T})-F^{*}\right]\leq\\ \frac{L/\mu}{KE}\left[\frac{2}{\mu}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}^{2}\sigma_{k}^{2}+6L\Gamma+8(E-1)^{2}G^{2}+4E^{2}G^{2}B\right)+\frac{\mu\gamma}{2}\left\|w_{0}-w^{*}\right\|^{2}\right], (12)

where T=K​E𝑇𝐾𝐸T=KE and B𝐵B is defined in Theorem 1.

By taking the derivative of the right hand side with respect to E𝐸E, we observe that the upper bound in Corollary 1 first decreases and then increases; thus, an optimal value for E𝐸E exists. In fact this can be easily understood by considering that increasing E𝐸E at first allows each device to move further in the direction of the optimal model parameters; thus, increases the convergence. However, when E𝐸E is set to a large value, each device moves towards its local optimum model instead of the global optimum.

It is also obvious that the upper bound in Corollary 1 is a decreasing function of K𝐾K and ℓℓ\ell, i.e. the algorithm converges faster as we increase the number of communications. However, increasing K𝐾K increases the rate of convergence more than increasing ℓℓ\ell. To prove this statement, we denote the success probability after ℓℓ\ell transmission attempts by Uk(ℓ)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘ℓU_{k}^{(\ell)}. According to (Appendix A: Proof of Lemma 1),

Uk(ℓ)superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘ℓ\displaystyle U_{k}^{(\ell)} =\displaystyle= 1−𝔼ΦI​[(1−e−θ​σ2​rkα​∏x∈ΦI11+θ​rkα​‖x‖−α)ℓ]1subscript𝔼subscriptΦIdelimited-[]superscript1superscript𝑒𝜃superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝛼subscriptproduct𝑥subscriptΦI11𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥𝛼ℓ\displaystyle 1-\mathbb{E}_{\Phi_{\rm I}}\left[\left(1-e^{-\theta\sigma^{2}r_{k}^{\alpha}}\prod_{x\in\Phi_{\rm I}}\frac{1}{1+\theta r_{k}^{\alpha}\|x\|^{-\alpha}}\right)^{\ell}\right] (13)
≤(a)superscript(a)\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{(a)}}}{{\leq}} 1−𝔼ΦI​[1−ℓ​e−θ​σ2​rkα​∏x∈ΦI11+θ​rkα​‖x‖−α]1subscript𝔼subscriptΦIdelimited-[]1ℓsuperscript𝑒𝜃superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝛼subscriptproduct𝑥subscriptΦI11𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘𝛼superscriptnorm𝑥𝛼\displaystyle 1-\mathbb{E}_{\Phi_{\rm I}}\left[1-\ell e^{-\theta\sigma^{2}r_{k}^{\alpha}}\prod_{x\in\Phi_{\rm I}}\frac{1}{1+\theta r_{k}^{\alpha}\|x\|^{-\alpha}}\right]
≤\displaystyle\leq ℓ​Uk(1),ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘1\displaystyle\ell U_{k}^{(1)},

where, in (a), we have used Bernoulli’s inequality [24]. When we increase K𝐾K to ℓ​Kℓ𝐾\ell K, from the upper bound in Corollary 1 we observe

L/μℓ​K​E​[Constant1+Constant2×∑k=1Npkqk​Uk(1)]𝐿𝜇ℓ𝐾𝐸delimited-[]subscriptConstant1subscriptConstant2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘1\displaystyle\frac{L/\mu}{\ell KE}\left[\textbf{Constant}_{1}+\textbf{Constant}_{2}\times\sum_{k=1}^{N}\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}U_{k}^{(1)}}\right] ≤\displaystyle\leq L/μK​E​[Constant1+Constant2×∑k=1Npkℓ​qk​Uk(1)]𝐿𝜇𝐾𝐸delimited-[]subscriptConstant1subscriptConstant2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘ℓsubscript𝑞𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑘1\displaystyle\frac{L/\mu}{KE}\left[\textbf{Constant}_{1}+\textbf{Constant}_{2}\times\sum_{k=1}^{N}\frac{p_{k}}{\ell q_{k}U_{k}^{(1)}}\right]

where we have used (13) in (a). Although increasing K𝐾K is more powerful compared to increasing ℓℓ\ell in improving the convergence rate, it consumes more resources since, during each round of the learning process, the scheduled devices perform E𝐸E steps of local update.

IV-B Scheduling Policy

In this subsection, we find the optimal scheduling policy for Scheme II. In this regard, we first find the solution to the following optimization problem: {mini}—r— {q_k} E[F(w_T)] \addConstraint∑_k=1^Nq_k=M \addConstraintq_k¿0,   ∀k∈{1,…,N}. The first condition is due to the fact that the BS allocates M𝑀M resource blocks for the learning process. Using the upper bound in Theorem 1 as an approximation of 𝔼​[F​(wT)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤𝑇superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}\left[F(w_{T})-F^{*}\right], we can obtain the solution to (IV-B) by solving {mini}—r— {q_k} ∑_k=1^NpkUkq_k^-1 \addConstraint∑_k=1^Nq_k=M \addConstraintq_k¿0,   ∀k∈{1,…,N}. Now, consider the following optimization {mini}—r— {q_k} ∑_k=1^NpkUkq_k^-1 \addConstraint∑_k=1^Nq_k≤M \addConstraintq_k¿0,   ∀k∈{1,…,N}. By contradiction, one can easily prove that solution to (IV-B), denoted by q1∗,…,qN∗superscriptsubscript𝑞1…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑁q_{1}^{*},...,q_{N}^{*}, satisfies ∑k=1Nqk∗=Msuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑘𝑀\sum_{k=1}^{N}q^{*}_{k}=M. Thus, (IV-B) is equivalent to (IV-B), i.e. q1∗,…,qN∗superscriptsubscript𝑞1…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑁q_{1}^{*},...,q_{N}^{*} is also the solution to (IV-B). (IV-B) is a geometric program, and it can be transformed to a convex problem [25]. Therefore, we can find q1∗,…,qN∗superscriptsubscript𝑞1…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑁q_{1}^{*},...,q_{N}^{*} using CVX or any other convex solver [26]. Finally, the optimal policy for Scheme II is achieved when q^k=qk∗Msubscript^𝑞𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑀\hat{q}_{k}=\frac{q_{k}^{*}}{M}. Note that the optimal policy for Scheme II does not necessarily perform better than Scheme I since convergence rate and the upper bound in Theorem 1 for Scheme I are different from Scheme II. In fact, it is only guaranteed that, with optimal policy for Scheme II, the upper bound in Theorem 1 performs better compared to other Scheme II scheduling policies.

Remark: Scheme I samples uniformly without replacement which yields qk=MNsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑀𝑁q_{k}=\frac{M}{N} for this scheme. Nevertheless, Theorem 1 is given for any value of qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} for Scheme I. Thus, we can derive q1∗,…,qN∗superscriptsubscript𝑞1…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑁q_{1}^{*},...,q_{N}^{*} for this scheme. Actually, q1∗,…,qN∗superscriptsubscript𝑞1…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑁q_{1}^{*},...,q_{N}^{*} for Scheme I and Scheme II are identical. However, unlike Scheme II, it is not possible to calculate the probabilities for Scheme I from q1∗,…,qN∗superscriptsubscript𝑞1…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑁q_{1}^{*},...,q_{N}^{*}.

Finally, it is worth mentioning that, according to Lemma 3, the optimal scheduling policy minimizes the variance of the updated global model at each averaging step.

IV-C Comparison with the Existing Works

Existing works, such as [11, 12, 6, 7], assume that the BS always successfully recovers the transmitted information of the scheduled devices. For example, [12, 6, 14] use sampling Scheme II with probabilities {pk}subscript𝑝𝑘\{p_{k}\} besides the following averaging approach:

wt=1M​∑k=1N∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮t−E​(m))​vtksubscript𝑤𝑡1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝐸𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑡𝑘\displaystyle w_{t}=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}_{t-E}(m)\right)v_{t}^{k}

at t∈ℐE𝑡subscriptℐ𝐸t\in\mathcal{I}_{E}. To study this averaging approach when unsuccessful transmission probability is greater than zero, we modify it as

wt={wt−Eif ​∑k=1N∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮t−E​(m),SINRk,m>θ)=01M​∑k=1N∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮t−E​(m),SINRk,m>θ)​vtkotherwise .subscript𝑤𝑡casessubscript𝑤𝑡𝐸otherwiseif superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1formulae-sequence𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝐸𝑚subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝜃0otherwise1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1formulae-sequence𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝐸𝑚subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑡𝑘otherwiseotherwise otherwise\displaystyle w_{t}=\begin{cases}w_{t-E}\\ \qquad\qquad\qquad\text{if }\sum_{k=1}^{N}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}_{t-E}(m),\text{SINR}_{k,m}>\theta\right)=0\\ \frac{1}{M}\sum_{k=1}^{N}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}_{t-E}(m),\text{SINR}_{k,m}>\theta\right)v_{t}^{k}\\ \qquad\qquad\qquad\text{otherwise }\end{cases}. (14)

In the following, we prove that this averaging scheme does not solve (1) when unsuccessful transmission probability is greater than zero and varies across the devices. In this regard, we focus on the following averaging approach:

wt=wt−E+∑k=1N∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮t−E​(m),SINRk,m>θ)∑k=1N∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮t−E​(m),SINRk,m>θ)​(vtk−wt−E),t∈ℐE,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑡subscript𝑤𝑡𝐸superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1formulae-sequence𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝐸𝑚subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1formulae-sequence𝑘subscript𝒮𝑡𝐸𝑚subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑡𝑘subscript𝑤𝑡𝐸𝑡subscriptℐ𝐸\displaystyle w_{t}=w_{t-E}+\sum_{k=1}^{N}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\frac{\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}_{t-E}(m),\text{SINR}_{k,m}>\theta\right)}{\sum_{k=1}^{N}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}_{t-E}(m),\text{SINR}_{k,m}>\theta\right)}\left(v_{t}^{k}-w_{t-E}\right),\qquad t\in\mathcal{I}_{E},
(15)

where we define 00=0000\frac{0}{0}=0. It is straightforward to show that, when M=1𝑀1M=1, (15) is same as (14).

In Appendix C, we prove that by using (15) for updating the global model parameters at t∈ℐE𝑡subscriptℐ𝐸t\in\mathcal{I}_{E}, instead of (1), the algorithm converges to the solution to the following problem:

minwF^​(w)=∑k=1Npk​Uk​Fk​(w).subscript𝑤^𝐹𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑈𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘𝑤\displaystyle\min_{w}\qquad\hat{F}(w)=\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}U_{k}F_{k}(w). (16)

Since (15) and (14) are equal for M=1𝑀1M=1, we can conclude that the employed learning approach by [12, 6, 14] do not always solve (1). In fact, one can easily understand that (14) is biased towards devices with higher success probabilities.

V Simulation Results and Discussion

Cellular Network: BS intensity λ𝜆\lambda is 0.001 (points/area). We assume in each cell there are N=100𝑁100N=100 user devices and each BS allocates only M=20𝑀20M=20 resource blocks for the distributed learning process. We also set σ2=10−4superscript𝜎2superscript104\sigma^{2}=10^{-4}, α=4𝛼4\alpha=4, and θ=−15​dB𝜃15dB\theta=-15\,{\rm dB}.

Datasets: We evaluate our proposed federated learning on both real and synthetic datasets. For real data, we use MNIST [27] and distribute our data similar to [6] in a non-i.i.d. fashion. Specifically, each sample in MNIST dataset is a 28×\times28 image of a handwritten digit between 0 to 9. We distribute the dataset samples such that each device has samples of only two digits and the number of samples at different devices is different. For synthetic data, we follow the same setup as in [28, 6, 12]. In this regard, we generate samples at device k𝑘k, denoted by (Xk,Yk)subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘(X_{k},Y_{k}), using y=argmax​(softmax​(Wk​x+bk))𝑦argmaxsoftmaxsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑥subscript𝑏𝑘y=\text{argmax}\left(\text{softmax}\left(W_{k}x+b_{k}\right)\right), where Wk∈ℝ10×60subscript𝑊𝑘superscriptℝ1060W_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 60} and bk∈ℝ10subscript𝑏𝑘superscriptℝ10b_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{10}. Each element in Wksubscript𝑊𝑘W_{k} and bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} is a realization of 𝒩​(μk,1)𝒩subscript𝜇𝑘1\mathcal{N}(\mu_{k},1), where μk∼𝒩​(0,α~)similar-tosubscript𝜇𝑘𝒩0~𝛼\mu_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\tilde{\alpha}). Thus, α~~𝛼\tilde{\alpha} controls the degree of difference between local models at different devices555When α~=0~𝛼0\tilde{\alpha}=0, elements of Wksubscript𝑊𝑘W_{k} and bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} at all devices are drawn from the same distribution, i.e. 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01\mathcal{N}(0,1). [12]. Moreover, x∈ℝ60𝑥superscriptℝ60x\in\mathbb{R}^{60}. The j𝑗j-th element (feature) in x𝑥x is drawn from 𝒩​(vk,j,j−1.2)𝒩subscript𝑣𝑘𝑗superscript𝑗1.2\mathcal{N}(v_{k,j},j^{-1.2}), where vk,j∼𝒩​(Bk,1)similar-tosubscript𝑣𝑘𝑗𝒩subscript𝐵𝑘1v_{k,j}\sim\mathcal{N}(B_{k},1)666vk,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑗v_{k,j} remains the same across j𝑗j-th feature of different samples of device k𝑘k. and Bk∼𝒩​(0,β~)similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑘𝒩0~𝛽B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\tilde{\beta}). Thus, β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta} controls the data heterogeneity. Finally, the number of data samples at device k𝑘k, denoted by nksubscript𝑛𝑘n_{k}, follows a power law distribution. In this paper, we set α~=1~𝛼1\tilde{\alpha}=1 and β~=1~𝛽1\tilde{\beta}=1.

Model: To examine the performance of the proposed FL algorithm on the discussed datasets, we use a three layer neural network with 300 hidden units at each hidden layer. For MNIST datatset, input of the model is a flattened 784-dimensional image. For the synthetic dataset, an input of the model has 60 dimensions. We use ReLU (rectified linear unit) activation function for the hidden layers and softmax in the output layer. At the beginning of round k𝑘k, k∈{0,1,2,…,K−1}𝑘012…𝐾1k\in\{0,1,2,...,K-1\}, we set the learning rate as ηt=η01+ksubscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝜂01𝑘\eta_{t}=\frac{\eta_{0}}{1+k}, where k​E≤t<(k+1)​E𝑘𝐸𝑡𝑘1𝐸kE\leq t<(k+1)E. We measure the performance of our model with regularized cross-entropy loss, where we use ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm regularization with regularization parameter 10−4superscript10410^{-4}.

Benchmark: When M=N𝑀𝑁M=N and Uk=1subscript𝑈𝑘1U_{k}=1, ∀k​{1,…,N}for-all𝑘1…𝑁\forall k\{1,...,N\}, the BS receives the local model parameters of all devices successfully. Under this assumption, if all devices use their full batch and E=1𝐸1E=1, the distributed learning algorithm is equivalent to the centralized full batch gradient descent. This scenario can be regarded as a benchmark for our proposed algorithm. In Fig. 2, performance of the centralized full gradient descent with η0=1subscript𝜂01\eta_{0}=1 is shown in terms of global loss and accuracy over both MNIST and synthetic datasets.

Training: To train the local models at local SGD steps, for MNIST dataset, we use batch sizes of 64 and set η0=1subscript𝜂01\eta_{0}=1. For the synthetic dataset, we use batch sizes of 25 and set η0=0.1subscript𝜂00.1\eta_{0}=0.1. Since we use a smaller learning rate for the synthetic dataset, we consider higher values for E𝐸E at the time of simulation. Our codes are available at [29].

Results777To make a fair comparison, we have illustrated the average performance over multiple trials.: In Fig. 3(a) and (b), we measure the performance of the proposed FL algorithm in terms of global loss and accuracy on MNIST dataset; Fig. 3(c) and (d) also illustrate the performance on the synthetic dataset. For Scheme II, we show the results with q^k=1Nsubscript^𝑞𝑘1𝑁\hat{q}_{k}=\frac{1}{N}, i.e. uniform selection and q^k=qk∗Msubscript^𝑞𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑘𝑀\hat{q}_{k}=\frac{q^{*}_{k}}{M}, i.e. optimal selection. For MNIST dataset, the objective function of (IV-B) at q1=q2=…=qN=MNsubscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2…subscript𝑞𝑁𝑀𝑁q_{1}=q_{2}=...=q_{N}=\frac{M}{N} is 7.09 and at the optimal point q1∗,q2∗,…,qN∗superscriptsubscript𝑞1superscriptsubscript𝑞2…superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑁q_{1}^{*},q_{2}^{*},...,q_{N}^{*} is 6.48. For the synthetic dataset, these values are 6.89 and 3.66, respectively. Thus, optimal scheduling has more effect on the synthetic dataset which can also be understood from Fig. 3. By calculating B𝐵B in Theorem 1 for Scheme I and Scheme II with optimal scheduling, we expect that Scheme I performs better on MNIST dataset and Scheme II performs better on the synthetic dataset. This is also illustrated is Fig. 3 and is in compliance with our discussion in Section IV.B. Moreover, as explained in Section IV.C, previous works, such as [12, 6, 14], cannot be used for wireless networks since they do not include unsuccessful transmission probability. This is also shown in Fig. 3, where we illustrate the performance of the introduced setup in Section IV.C.

We provide more simulation results in Fig. 4, 5, 6, and 7 where we study the effects of K𝐾K, ℓℓ\ell, and E𝐸E on the performance of our algorithm. For Scheme I sampling, we show the results in Fig. 4 and 6. For Scheme II sampling with q^k=1Nsubscript^𝑞𝑘1𝑁\hat{q}_{k}=\frac{1}{N}, we show the results in Fig. 5 and 7. Note that, when q^k=1Nsubscript^𝑞𝑘1𝑁\hat{q}_{k}=\frac{1}{N} in Scheme II, both schemes select users uniformly; however, Scheme I selects without replacement, while replacement is allowed in Scheme II. We see that Scheme I performs better than Scheme II with uniform selection. This can be also understood from Theorem 1. Finally, it is worth mentioning that, with appropriate tuning of the hyper-parameters (K𝐾K, ℓℓ\ell, and E𝐸E), we can reach the benchmarked performance levels.

VI Conclusion

Federated learning algorithms cannot be employed in the real world scenarios unless they consider the scarcity of radio resources and unreliability of wireless transmissions. In this regard, in this paper, we have proposed a federated learning algorithm that is tailored for unreliable and resource-constrained wireless networks, where success probability varies across different devices. Our proposed federated learning algorithm incorporates the success probability in the averaging step. Thus, as the first step towards designing the FL algorithm, we have used stochastic geometry tools to calculate the success probability. We have studied the convergence of the proposed algorithm. Specifically, we have proven that the algorithm converges with rate 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{T}) for strongly convex and smooth problems on non-i.i.d. data. The effects of computation, communication, and scheduling on the convergence rate of the algorithm have also been investigated. Finally, we have verified our algorithm through experimenting on real and synthetic datasets.

Appendix B: Proof of Theorem 1888We follow the same procedure as in [6]. Therefore, we mainly focus on the parts that are different.

When we choose the learning rate as ηt=βμ​(γ+t)subscript𝜂𝑡𝛽𝜇𝛾𝑡\eta_{t}=\frac{\beta}{\mu(\gamma+t)} with β>0𝛽0\beta>0 and γ=max⁡{4​β​Lμ,E}𝛾4𝛽𝐿𝜇𝐸\gamma=\max\left\{4\beta\frac{L}{\mu},E\right\}, it fulfills the following properties: i) ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is decreasing with respect to t𝑡t, ii) ηt≤12​Lsubscript𝜂𝑡12𝐿\eta_{t}\leq\frac{1}{2L}, ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t, and iii) ηt≤2​ηt+Esubscript𝜂𝑡2subscript𝜂𝑡𝐸\eta_{t}\leq 2\eta_{t+E}, ∀tfor-all𝑡\forall t. These properties help us with the convergence analysis of the proposed federated learning algorithm.

In the following, we provide three lemmas which help us in proving the theorem.

Lemma 2.

Averaging step in the proposed algorithm is unbiased, i.e.

where the expectation is over sampling and success event.

In Scheme I, at the aggregation step, each device can use at most one resource block. Thus,

𝔼​[(∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮​(m),SINRk,m>θ))2]=𝔼​[∑m=1M𝟏​(k∈𝒮​(m),SINRk,m>θ)]=qk​Uk.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1formulae-sequence𝑘𝒮𝑚subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝜃2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀1formulae-sequence𝑘𝒮𝑚subscriptSINR𝑘𝑚𝜃subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑈𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}(m),\text{SINR}_{k,m}>\theta\right)\right)^{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{m=1}^{M}\mathbf{1}\left(k\in\mathcal{S}(m),\text{SINR}_{k,m}>\theta\right)\right]=q_{k}U_{k}.
(B.3)

∎

Lemma 4.

When ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} satisfies the aforementioned properties, for any t𝑡t, we have

𝔼​[‖v¯t+1−w∗‖2]≤(1−μ​ηt)​𝔼​[‖w¯t−w∗‖2]+ηt2​(∑k=1Npk2​σk2+6​L​Γ+8​(E−1)2​G2).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript¯𝑣𝑡1superscript𝑤21𝜇subscript𝜂𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript¯𝑤𝑡superscript𝑤2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘26𝐿Γ8superscript𝐸12superscript𝐺2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bar{v}_{t+1}-w^{*}\|^{2}\right]\leq(1-\mu\eta_{t})\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bar{w}_{t}-w^{*}\|^{2}\right]+\eta_{t}^{2}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}^{2}\sigma_{k}^{2}+6L\Gamma+8(E-1)^{2}G^{2}\right).
Proof:

See Appendix A in [6]. ∎

Note that Lemma 2 and Lemma 3 only consider t∈ℐE𝑡subscriptℐ𝐸t\in\mathcal{I}_{E}. When, t∉ℐE𝑡subscriptℐ𝐸t\not\in\mathcal{I}_{E}, w¯t=v¯tsubscript¯𝑤𝑡subscript¯𝑣𝑡\bar{w}_{t}=\bar{v}_{t} according to (LABEL:eq:Averaging).

Based on the above discussion, at any t𝑡t, we have

From (C.4), we understand that Lemma 2 holds (for problem (C.1)). Also, from (C.5), we understand that Lemma 3 holds with B=1𝐵1B=1. As we discussed earlier, Lemma 4 is also valid (after replacing pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} with αk′subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑘\alpha^{\prime}_{k}). Thus, following the same procedure as in Appendix B, we can prove that with using (15) at averaging steps, at time T∈ℐE𝑇subscriptℐ𝐸T\in\mathcal{I}_{E}, we have

𝔼​[‖wT−w^∗‖2]≤max⁡{4μ2​(∑k=1Nαk′⁣ 2​σk2+6​L​Γ+8​(E−1)2​G2+4​E2​G2),γ​‖w0−w^∗‖2}γ+T.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑇superscript^𝑤24superscript𝜇2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘′2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘26𝐿Γ8superscript𝐸12superscript𝐺24superscript𝐸2superscript𝐺2𝛾superscriptnormsubscript𝑤0superscript^𝑤2𝛾𝑇\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{w}_{T}-\hat{w}^{*}\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\frac{\max\left\{\frac{4}{\mu^{2}}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}^{\prime\,2}\sigma_{k}^{2}+6L\Gamma+8(E-1)^{2}G^{2}+4E^{2}G^{2}\right),\gamma\left\|w_{0}-\hat{w}^{*}\right\|^{2}\right\}}{\gamma+T}.

Hence, the algorithm converges to the solution to (C.1).
